result.execSummary:
The defendant David J. Bannister was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct - County/Municipality. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

11:11 AM Defendant David J. Bannister in court.  Attorney Adrian W Longacre in court for David J. Bannister.  Attorney Harper on behalf of Attorney Amy Elizabeth Forehand in court for State of Wisconsin. Attorney Longacre informs the court that they will be entering a plea to disorderly conduct ordinance violation for $50 plus costs. State moves to amend to 79.4 on count 1. Attorney Longacre enters a NC plea on behalf of  his client. Court orders $50 plus costs on count 1 with 30 dtp. Count 2 - DRI.

Hearing on motion to amend bond re contact with victim. State opposes the request. Counsel address the court. Court wants to know if the request is the victim's current request; information presented today is that victim does not want contact though something could be worked through a third party but the Court wants more information on that and directs VWC to ask victim if contact through stated family member is okay. Atty. Forehand - if victim consents to that arrangement, the matter can be recorded via stipulation.

records.addlTxt: Adjourned initial appearance on February 18, 2022 at 10:00 am.

01:12 PM Defendant David J. Bannister appeared by video means. Prosecuting Atty Amy Elizabeth Forehand appeared for State of Wisconsin.  DB has recieved the complaint. DB states that he doesn't qualify for the public defender. 

Court reviews financial information and appoints Attorney Longacre. Defendant to deposit $50/month with the Clerk of Court starting on 02/01/22 . At the end of the case, counsel will file their bill and the Defendant will be required to fully reimburse Richland County. The Defendant will need to complete a payment plan form with the Clerk of Court.  Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for February 18, 2022 at 10:00 am.
